data.title: Separation of glyphs and characters for BitmapFontCache
data.body:
This PR refactors how BitmapFontCache works. Previously it was assumed each character in a string mapped to a glyph for display. As discussed in #1589, this is not the case for some types of font rendering. This PR has two main goals: 1) to separate characters and glyphs, 2) to make parsing the string and preparing for display cleaner. The new approach works like this:
1. GlyphLayout, a new class, is given a string of characters. It first breaks the strings into "runs". A run is a string of characters all the same color and without newlines. The reason to break the text into runs is that each run can be "shaped" individually, which means to convert the characters into glyphs for display. When breaking the string into runs, GlyphLayout parses color markup tags and stores the color for each run.
2. Next, the runs are shaped using a new BitmapFontData method, `getGlyphs`. This takes the characters for the run and generates both a list of glyphs and a list of positions for each glyph. The default implementation just looks up the glyph for the character as has always been done. A more complex implementation could use [HarfBuzz](http://www.freedesktop.org/wiki/Software/HarfBuzz/) or another lib to do the shaping.
3. Next, the shaped runs are laid out. If wrapping is enabled and a run's glyphs exceed the wrap width, then glyphs are split for line wrapping using another new BitmapFontData method, `getWrapIndex`. The run is ended, the remaining glyphs are moved to a new run on the next line, and the layout process repeats. I'm not sure if line wrapping glyphs is the best solution, but at least where the wrap happens can be customized. Once all runs are laid out, if center or right alignment is requested then run positions are shifted appropriately.
4. At this point GlyphLayout is done. It stores the `Array<GlyphRun>` and provides a width and height which is the bounds of all the runs. Previously getting text bounds required all the work of laying out the glyphs, which then had to be repeated for drawing. With GlyphLayout, the work is only done once. Each GlyphRun has `Array<Glyph>` and a `FloatArray` for the positions.
5. Next comes BitmapFontCache. This class now has an `Array<GlyphLayout>` and its job is to store the vertex data for rendering the glyphs in those GlyphLayouts. Most of BitmapFontCache was left intact, eg it still can render from multiple texture regions.

There are a number of relatively small API breaking changes:
1. The BitmapFontCache `setText`, `setMultilineText`, `setWrappedText`, and similar `addXxx` methods are replaced by `setText` and `addText`. The number of overloads was kept reasonable. The same happened to the BitmapFont draw methods, which delegate to BitmapFontCache. These methods all return GlyphLayout instead of TextBounds.
2. BitmapFont.TextBounds is deprecated. I should have never added it and just used Vector2. Now, GlyphLayout has `width` and `height` and replaces TextBounds.
3. BitmapFont.HAlignment is gone. Align is used instead.
4. `markupEnabled` was moved to BitmapFontData.
5. BitmapFont `getBounds` and related methods were mostly removed, with the single most commonly used method deprecated. GlyphLayout should be used directly to avoid computing glyphs multiple times.
6. BitmapFont `computeGlyphAdvancesAndPositions` and `computeVisibleGlyphs` are deprecated and should be removed because they assume a 1:1 mapping of characters to glyphs. GlyphLayout can be used instead, which provides each glyph position. ~~I haven't made this change since it affects TextField and friends, but I will once this gets merged.~~ Now done.

Feedback on these changes is welcome. I've used the gdx-tests to verify things are still working. I also have updated Spine to use this, which is relatively complex real world usage. The font APIs are widely used so it's important we get this right. Now is a good time to break the API further if we need to.

data.title: Music is not paused / muted when window is deactivate / minimized on desktop
java.lang.NullPointerException at com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.TextMarkup.setDefaultChunk(TextMarkup.java:192)
data.body:
I'm running the latest version of libgdx (1.5.4) on an Android device running 4.0.4 and I got the same exception as #2772.

``` java
java.lang.NullPointerException at
com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.TextMarkup.setDefaultChunk(TextMarkup.java:192) at
com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.TextMarkup.clear(TextMarkup.java:159) at
com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.BitmapFontCache.clear(BitmapFontCache.java:329) at
com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.BitmapFontCache.setText(BitmapFontCache.java:571)
```

I've only seen it happen once so I'm not sure if I can recreate it.

data.title: Vector2 angleRad() method always returns 0 or pi if current Vector2 is (0,0)
data.body: If I have a Vector2 pos1 at (0,0) and a Vector2 pos2 at any other point beside (0,0) like (1,1) and then do pos1.angleRad(pos2) it will return 0 or pi depending on the value of pos2 and never any other values.

data.title: Update BillboardParticleBatch
data.body:
Allow to customize blendingAttribute and depthTestAttribute in BillboardParticleBatch.
This commit does not change the API.

Lot of the modified lines are just my Eclipse cleaning code during save.

data.title: Add Spotlight support in Default shader.
data.body:
Add the support of spotlight in default shader.
Tests have been written to valid the good execution.

data.title: Stage2Ds ScrollPane sets alpha for the batch and doesn't reset it
data.body: The ScrollPane sets the alpha of the batch it is passed to fade it's scrollbars. It is not reset after it's draw call finishes which leads to objects not related to the UI disappearing when in the same batch as a ScrollPane.

data.title: Can't find locations of extensions? .dll files in appdata
data.body: In the box2d library, there is a settings file which lets you adjust performance variables such as max vertex count. However, i cannot find this .cpp file anywhere. It is not in libgdx.jar, box2d.jar, etc. I don't know how the "box-2d" class files are loaded through the dll's but i would like to change properties of the box2d extension. How can i do this?

data.title: ProgressBar#setAnimateDuration(float) is broken
iOS 8.2: NPE in IOSApplication while calling getIosVersion()
data.body:
To be honest, I don't know if that's a libgdx or a RoboVM issue. My app crashes on iOS as soon as didFinishLaunching is reached since I updated to 8.2.

iPod Touch with iOS 8.2
RoboVM 1.0.0
libgdx 1.5.5

``` java.lang.NullPointerException
    at com.badlogic.gdx.backends.iosrobovm.IOSApplication.getIosVersion(IOSApplication.java)
    at com.badlogic.gdx.backends.iosrobovm.IOSApplication$Delegate.didFinishLaunching(IOSApplication.java)
    at org.robovm.apple.uikit.UIApplicationDelegate$ObjCProxy.$cb$application$didFinishLaunchingWithOptions$(Unknown Source)
    at org.robovm.apple.uikit.UIApplication.main(Native Method)
    at org.robovm.apple.uikit.UIApplication.main(UIApplication.java)
    at ch.gearsoft.sleepwell.IOSLauncher.main(IOSLauncher.java)
```

data.title: libgdx-utils as 3rd party extension
data.body:
I'd like to add my little support library as a 3rd party extension to the gdx-setup app. Users already asked for this in the past before the XML configuration existed.

> Does your project aim to extend LibGDX with a specific goal in mind?

The goal is to offer additional features (like pre-made scene2d.ui widgets, the `TmxMapWriter`, `AnnotationAssetManager` or the [`PolygonRegionLoader`](https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/pull/1602) which was merged into libGDX) and utility/helper classes to make game dev even more convenient. I'd let that count as specific enough even though it's rather broad.

> Is your project useful to LibGDX users?

I think so, it's catered towards them.

> Is your project well established?

Depends on what is well established enough. The repository currently has 9 forks and 46 watchers on Bitbucket. The only statistics I have are those from sonatype:
![chart](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4956158/6659805/550ce006-cb8d-11e4-9bc3-175e20c62f51.png)

> Your project is well maintained

There was not a single month without commits since I started this project in September 2013 and it's usually compatible with the latest libGDX release.

data.title: missing ClassReflection#isArray(Class)
data.body: The equivalent of `Class#isArray()` would be nice to have in `ClassReflection`.

data.title: [GWT] HttpResponse.getHeaders() returns null
Fix lwjgl opengl - opengl es version check
data.body:
Currently the lwjgl version check might cause some issues (e.g. when the version vendor string contains the string "2.1"). For GLES3 the OpenGL 3.2 core profile [was used](https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/commit/08711a2152eda79f20c2db6064b4f1b444b6ea0c), while afaik GLES3 requires at least 4.3. Also, currently GLES3 is enabled even if not requested. This PR tries to fix these issues along with some minor changes. E.g. I've moved all the version checking into separate methods for readability and added links to the resources on which the implementation is based. Also moved the extensions to an array instead of long string. Since I was at it, I also added a `compatibleWithGLES2` method. While currently not used, this method could be used to implement the currently missing methods for true GLES 2 compatibility. I added an argument to the `createDisplayPixelFormat` method so it can fallback without modifying the config in case 4.3+ is not available and useGL30 is requested.

Problem is that I can't test it, other than on my PC which supports OpenGL 4.5.

data.title: [gdx-jnigen] ARM compatibility
data.body:
I've been working on a project which uses gdx-jnigen for generating and loading native libraries. The project runs on any linux, and is most beneficial on a Raspberry Pi, which has the ARM architecture. 
Currently it is not possible to build a version for 32bit, 64bit and arm architectures at the same time. Therefore, I added some options to the buildscript generator, which gives more freedom, also for future additions.
I also added the ability to detect an ARM platform, and load the appropriate native library.

This will be usefull in all sorts of projects, and will also be helpfull if one would decide to port libgdx to another ARM platform (Iike the Rpi) later.

data.title: Project Generator creating ghost projects
data.body:
Hi there,

I'm using the Libgdx project generator on Windows 8.1.
Log indicates the build was successful but I cannot find it using Windows Explorer, nor Android Studio. Tried with git bash, same result. Though, when I use the `Browse' button on the project generator and go into the destination folder, I can see the project has been successfully created.

Long story short : in my case, libgdx project generator creates ghost directories and files that I cannot access, unless using the project generator.

**EDIT:** Using another file explorer such as _explorer++_, I was able to access those files and delete those. But I still find it weird that files cannot be accessed the usual way.

**EDIT 2:** Okay, the problem was caused by the fact my antivirus was automatically launching Libgdx project generator into a sandbox. Disabled that thing, and now it works!

data.title: Fix TextField not respecting onlyFontChars
data.body:
`onlyFontChars` behaviour was not consistent. It did allow those chars to be pasted, but not written.

For reference, I was using this for emulating iOS text field behaviour when writing letters like . Those are written by pressing `e` and ``. Natively, those chars are combined when rendering (Unicode standard). However, libGDX does not support such combining, so I have to listen for input (setTextFieldListener -> keyTyped) and then combine the chars manually. Problem is, that `` is not written in the TextField text, because my font does not contain it, so I can not combine it easily.

data.title: Unable to use PolyRegion with a TextureAtlas
data.body:
Hey,

I was trying to reduce the draw calls in a prototype I was toying with, by replacing the individual textures with an atlas.

I am currently using a PolygonRegion with the appropriate batch. But unfortunately I can't get it to render my textures from my texture atlas correctly. It appears to a end up rendering the entire sprite sheet.

I have mocked up a really simple example using 1px textures, it can be downloaded from here - https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/13890121/Poly.zip. I render 2 square (or 4 triangles) the one on the right is from a straight up texture the on on the left is the atlas.

I appreciate I may be doing something wrong, this polygon stuff is fairly new to me. But the javadoc does say that the PolygonRegion class does support TextureAtlas'

Cheers

James

data.title: Fog error in animated ModelInstance
data.body: If i have a animated modelInstance, the fog don't work correctly. Looks like it calculates the postion on [0,0,0] not relative to the camera. In others no animated ModelInstance, it works normally.

data.title: gdx-setup: GWT inheritance support for 3rd party extensions
data.body:
Now `gwtInherit` field can be defined in `extensions.xml`. If defined, `inherits name='...'` will be added to `GwtDefinition.gwt.xml` and `GdxDefinitionSuperdev.gwt`

Dependency class now has `gwtInherits` field, so I was able to remove `gwtInheritances` map from `DepedencyBank`. For official extensions gwt inherits now is defined in `ProjectDependency` enum.

Also fixes bug in 3rd party extension dialog. `MouseListener` was used for listening for table changes, where `TableModelListener` should be used. When using `MouseListener` some events may be not reported, like here: [GIF](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4594081/6644029/3de7c6b2-c9b1-11e4-926e-167bb160cd4b.gif) (should print random int when check box was changed)
Because that listener is used for updating dependency list, user could check extension and it wouldn't be included.

data.title: Add FrameBufferCubemap class.
data.body:
This class allows to render in a cubemap framebuffer easily.

It's very useful for point light shadowing.
It works very well and it's documented.

data.title: Update 1.5.4
Node.insertChild never terminates in some conditions
Mesh.dispose() does not free memory on Linux
data.body:
Hi all

I am having trouble with a memory leak on the Linux Platform. My Programm generates a lot of Mesh.
So to save memory, it calls dispose on the unneeded mesh objects.
This works perfectly on Windows, but it has no effect on Linux.

After some debugging I gave up. If I had to guess, I would search the C++ parts, but I was unable to make sense there.

Regards dns2utf8
